creditline: Given in honor of Anne and Mike Birt from their children
description: zigzagging path up a mountain with buildings along route; round area at top of mountain with buildings; some figures walking along path; muted colors; inscription in black with one red seal, LRC; ivory roller ends
inscription: On box, in ink, top: 可明斎筆富士山之図 {Kameisai hitsu Fuji san no zu} (Brushed by Kameisai, picture of Mount Fuji); bottom: 絹本横幅 {kenpon yokohaba} (On horizontal silk)
signed: LRC in ink: 応需可明齋寫 {Ōju Kameisai sha} (Fulfilling a request, copied by Kameisai)
text: Mount Fuji, so often depicted with a smooth surface, here reveals its craggy face. People walk along a zigzagging path leading to the summit. Their white attire, straw hats, and walking sticks signal that they are pilgrims of the Fuji cult, which venerated the famous mountain as a god. The path upward is dotted with little huts, which were built and managed by local villagers for use by pilgrims. At the top of the mountain, five Buddhist sculptures are lined up in front of the crater, further highlighting the religious significance of the mountain. Though painters had depicted Mount Fuji since at least the 11th century, paintings and prints depicting routes up the mountain became common around the late 18th and early 19th centuries.
title: Pilgrims Climbing Mount Fuji
